div1.p:
Editorial
from
The News Leader, Richmond, Va. Nov. 10, 1914.
By Douglas Freeman.
Carter, Reed, Gorgas.

x Didn't come to Richmond with wood - its too far-
Did sell cross ties to the C. & O. at our R. R. station
x

A strong-faced, gray-haired visitor to Richmond went yesterday
afternoon to look for a cobble-stone on South Fifth Street.

He found it near the intersection of Cary and he told an old
friend who accompanied him how he became acquainted with that particu-
lar cobblestone. Forty-nine years ago, one April morning, he said,
his father put on his gray uniform, kissed him and his mother and
hurried away from their home near the old Confederate arsenal. The
father left strict orders for the boy: the arsenal was to be fired.
The flames might spread. If this happened and a certain nearby house
caught fire, the 11-year-old boy was to remove the family Lares and
was to go up Fifth street to an appointed place of refuge. In parti-
cular, he was to lead the cow to safety; whatever might be lost, that
cow must be saved.

It all befell as the Confederate brigadier had expected. The
works at the arsenal were soon in flames, shells began to explode,
houses were consumed, smoke issued from the dwelling the lad had been
directed to watch; he went about his work of salvage. It was not
easy--especially the removal of that cow. She had become alarmed at
the crackle of the flames and the whistle of shells and refused to
follow. But at length the boy had the rope about her horns and led
her up Fifth Street. He reached Cary--a veritable wall of smoke be-
hind him--and was starting up the hill to Main when many things hap-
pened at once. A fragment of an exploding shell from the arsenal de-
scended from the blue; it struck the cow; the cow bolted; the boy
fell and, falling, bumped his head against the very cobblestone he
identified yesterday.

We doubt if many in the panic-stricken city of Richmond had time
that dismal day to minister to a little lad with a cracked crown. We
doubt if many knew him except as the son of that great man, who, as
Confederate Chief of Ordnance, was one of the most invaluable of
Southern officers. But that boy became Surgeon-General William C.
Gorgas, whose fame as a sanitarian, ripened by his brilliant work at
Panama, is second to that of no living man.

The friend to whom Dr. Gorgas yesterday told the tragedy of the
cow and the cobblestone was of the same age and the same traditions.
He was not in Richmond on evacuation day, but in Hanover county,
where his parents lived. He had heard the rumors of disaster and had
seen the smoke of the flames which sent young Gorgas into the street
with the cow. Besides, in the years of poverty after the war, this
friend of the Surgeon-General had come to Richmond with a one-mule
wagon and had passed that very corner, perhaps, selling cordwood and
cedar posts to raise money for his medical education. That friend,
it is scarcely necessary to say, is Senior Surgeon Henry R. Carter,
whose early work on yellow fever made possible the experiments of
Walter Reed and the remarkable sanitary conquests of General Gorgas.
of General Gorgas.

The very mention of Reed completes the triumvirate. For while
young Gorgas was leading his cow up Fifth Street and young Carter, in
Hanover County, was wondering at war, the Gloucester County preacher's
boy was 14 years old, all unconscious of his future fame, and scarcely
thinking of medicine as a career.

We doubt if modern science records a like example of men of kin-
dred sympathy and almost common birth whose labors in the same field
of endeavor yielded such notable results. Carter and Reed were native
Virginians, Gorgas, as the son of General Josiah Gorgas, passed the
formative years of his life in this State and is knit to us by ties so
close that we always think of him as a Virginian. They never knew one-
another until manhood, but then they co-operated with splendid com-
radeship in the study of yellow fever--that baffling scourge of the
tropics. Dr. Carter worked out the period of extrinsic incubation, Dr.
Reed, at Columbia Barracks, Quemados, proved the responsibility of
the Stegomyia fasciata for the carriage of yellow fever; Dr. Gorgas,
first at Havana and then at Panama, worked out measures for the preven-
tion of the disease, without which, as all the world knows, the great-
est engineering feat of the ages, the completion of the Panama Canal,
could not have been accomplished.

The commonwealth that boasts great soldiers like Washington,
Jackson and Lee, great jurists like Wythe, Marshall and Roane and
great statesmen like Jefferson, Madison and Monroe rejoices that she
has a claim on three of the greatest benefactors of our day--Carter,
Reed and Gorgas.
